intro: Lycopsis virginica, commonly known as the Virginia lycopus, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the mint family (Lamiaceae) and is characterized by its square stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, blue to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, wooded areas and is often found in wetlands or along stream banks. Lycopsis virginica is valued for its ornamental appeal and historical use in herbal medicine.
